newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey to import wheat, export barley.
newsitem.headline: Turkey to import wheat, export barley.

text.p: Turkey's state Grain Board (TMO) will import an unspecified amount of wheat soon to stabilise domestic wheat prices, which surged after the government held up a U.S. wheat cargo on grounds it might contain fungus, a senior TMO official said on Monday.
He said the government agency would also export up to 250,000 tonnes of feed barley from its surplus this year.
"There is a consensus among the related ministers of the government to import wheat," he said."We will import the wheat as soon as possible."

Turkish milling wheat prices rose to 27,000 lira per kilo ($277 per tonne) this week from 20,000 lira two weeks ago after the agriculture ministry said it was inspecting a cargo of 15,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat, which is currently the chief supply for Turkish millers.
Officials said the TMO might invite tenders for small cargoes so as not to spark a rise in world prices.
An analyst said the initial amount could be 100,000 to 150,000 tonnes of milling wheat.

The official also said the TMO, which bought about 600,000 tonnes of feed barley from farmers this year and exported 125,000 tonnes of it through a tender in September, would export up to 250,000 tonnes of feed barley towards the end of this month.
He also said the TMO would sell part of its durum wheat purchases of 600,000 tonnes from farmers to local pasta producers after an expected government decree.
The decree would enable the TMO to sell durum locally at world prices, usually 20 percent below domestic prices.
The difference would be offset by the treasury.
